We asked 80 of the most interesting people we know—chefs, novelists, activists, comedians, NBA players, and more—to let us in on their most-trusted haunts, from a Tibetan dumpling stand in a grocery store in Columbus to a landlocked fish market in Tulsa. These are the spots we return to again and again, the places that make no claim to be the “newest” or the “trendiest,” and that’s precisely why we love them.

Milpitas, CA
“My hometown has become a not-so-secret spot for food 
in the Bay Area, probably due to the fact that the food in Milpitas—a majority-minority town for as long as I’ve lived there—is generally made both by and for the community. Pinoy BBQ ATBP, just off the tail-end of Highway 237, is no exception. With its sunset-orange Formica booths, walls plastered with Pacquiao posters, and a huge silver fork and spoon hung on display (a decorative mainstay in many 
a Filipino home and restaurant that tells you we’re serious about food), Pinoy BBQ ATBP is a temple to the kind 
of food that rarely gets lavish write-ups but actually feeds a community. I’m but one member of its parish. Go for the solid, occasionally transcendent barbecue, the oxtail kare-kare (sometimes they even serve goat, vanishingly rare in the Bay), the refrigerator full of guyabano and guava juices, the stand selling Choc Nut to go, the TV blaring Philippine news, and the knowledge that you are standing in the kind of place that should also be called America’s heartland, if we’re to be in any way honest about America, its land, or its heart.
Author, America Is Not the Heart


Elaine Castillo

If I don’t get the burger, I’ll order Uncle Lou’s fried chicken. On the menu it says something along the lines of ‘the only thing you can’t send back to the kitchen.’ And that’s true with everything at Playground. “When a restaurant gets all the hype, the one next to it doesn’t get the same attention, even though it’s just as good. That’s a phenomenon I see a lot of, especially near my old home in Los Feliz. Little Dom’s is the hipster place to go, but on the next block is Puran’s, the more bare-bones, less-stylish spot with food just as fantastic. They’re much more focused on the food than the decor or ironic wall art—and you don’t have to wait an hour. I had the best spicy shrimp linguine and Dover sole on couscous there, surrounded by red walls with old Italian movie posters hung haphazardly and Charlie Chaplin films playing from a projector. I’d go there once a week, usually on my own with a glass of Pinot Noir and a book.”

I’d usually get a burrito, then walk across the street to eat wings and watch the game. (The L.A. Clippers! They’re always the underdogs, but I’ve been supporting them since they sucked in 2000.) Sometimes they’d even let me bring the burrito inside Dirty Birds because I was there so much and knew the manager.
One of my dreams is to wrap those wings inside a burrito. I’d quit acting if I could open a chicken-wing burrito version
of Trujillo’s in L.A. Don’t tell my agent.”

Oklahoma City, OK
“The Metro feels like a second home. It’s a restaurant that my mom and dad went to all the time; they had their own special table and the waitstaff would take care of them so nicely. When Nick [Offerman] and I come into town at the last second, they always bend over backward and go overboard to accommodate us, even with a big group of our friends. I don’t think it’s the fact that we’re famous but more because we’re family. They have great ice cream, which we take back home for Mom if she can’t make it. There was a period of time when my mom wasn’t feeling well, and we were all very worried. We came to town for a bit, and everyone at The Metro was just incredibly kind and caring. It felt like going to a friend’s house, where they’re going to take care of you. The added bonus is that the food is also really, really good.”
Actress, Will & Grace

The Metro Wine Bar & Bistro


Austin, TX
“We don’t go out to eat that much, so when we do it’s usually to Picnik in Austin, which is about ten minutes from our house. The indoor and outdoor seating all merges together so you can enjoy a little of both. Matthew [McConaughey] and I take the kids there for crispy chicken tenders, and we’ll always get guacamole with homemade chips; brussels sprouts with pork belly, Parmesan, and maple syrup; and a few of the specials. We like to experiment and get whatever sounds good that day. Sometimes that’s the fish tacos, other times beef stew—depends on the weather and our moods. Everything is locally sourced, made from scratch, and feels kind 
of good for you without sacrificing taste. We all love it.”

Camila Alves 


Picnik


FOUNDER, WOMEN OF TODAY
Oxford, MS
“Tucked in a gas station north of the courthouse square in my hometown of Oxford, Mississippi, Zaap Thai Kitchen is a mom-and-pop for the 21st century, run by a mom named Rasita Palawan. Her massaman curry, bobbing with sweet potatoes, tossed with peanuts, and drizzled with coconut milk, tastes like the cloistered South I knew as a boy 
and the diverse South I now see coming into slow focus. For nine bucks and change, I get a gander of both, while slurping curry and rice and watching mud-splattered pickups loaded with ATV payloads queue at the pump.”
director, southern foodways alliance

John T. Edge


Zaap Thai Kitchen


Des Moines, IA
“For a fix of ​good food and conviviality, we go to the Cheese Bar in Des Moines. Run by proprietors C.J. and Kari Bienert, it’s casual and cool, delicious and friendly. They serve a great assortment of wines and beers; stellar cheeses, salumi, and charcuterie; fantastic sandwiches, including wonderful grilled ones; light and lovely salads; and the best mac and cheese ever, baked and served 
in its own cast-iron skillet so it stays creamy, crunchy, and piping hot all the way to the last bite.”
Owners, La Quercia

Kathy and Herb Eckhouse

Cheese Bar

“When my husband moved down to New Orleans five years ago to produce NCIS: New Orleans, he wanted a place walking distance from the house to have dinner every night because he doesn’t cook. So when I’m not in L.A. filming, Patois is like our second home. It’s cozy, and it feels like family is all around you. The first time I went there I had a fried oyster salad that may have had crispy chicken skins on top. We go every week now, so they know what I like—usually the lamb ribs made in a huge smoker on the sidewalk—but they wait to see what I’m up for that evening since I like to try something new every time. They always seem to have room, no matter how many friends or family members we have in tow.”
Actress, Young Sheldon

Chicago
“One of my favorite restaurants in the entire United States is D4 Irish Pub, which is a short walk from my apartment in Chicago. They’ve always been consistently superb. You surely won’t miss the extra big smile of my favorite server, Gorin, a man who knows no strangers. Sometimes I’ll go just to say hello but end up staying for the food. The portions are hefty—an appetizer could be shared by two—and I love their blackened salmon salad with mango vinaigrette, Caribbean jerk fish tacos, crab cake sliders, and beer-battered chicken tenders.”
Actor, Chicago P.D.

D4 Irish Pub and Café


New Orleans
“It’s a little off the French Quarter tourist track, but there’s always a line out the door at Casamento’s. It’s because 
of the oysters. The slim space is absolutely no frills (think fluorescent-lit diner), just fresh seafood. I grab a plate of raw oysters and a plate of charbroiled oysters with a 
cold beer. It’s heaven.”
author, Sweetbitter

Stephanie Danler 


Casamento’s


St. Louis, MO
“Since my wife and I moved back to St. Louis, we’ve been regulars at Loafers, as it’s known to those who know good bread. We have marked almost every milestone, good and bad, sitting at the same corner bar seats. When we were building our restaurant, we ate countless rare roast beef sandwiches and Little Gem salads, hashing out our business plan, getting to know the owners, and asking 
a million questions. Since we’ve opened, we still manage 
to sneak in a day date or pick up lunch to go once a week. It’s the kind of place where you walk in and know 
at least five other people in the place, sometimes even 
our own family members. Now we often see our regulars there, a very special full circle moment looking back to 
our first meals there when we didn’t know a soul in town.”
Chef, Vicia

Michael Gallina 

Union Loafers


Kansas City, MO
“Part of what makes me love this restaurant so much is that it reminds me of eating Chinese food as a child, before 
I became a chef and began obsessively seeking out ‘authenticity.’ The menu reads like a typical Midwestern Chinese restaurant, yet every item is the best version you can imagine: salt-and-pepper squid, golden noodles, crispy beef—pea shoots with sautéed shrimp—all classic American-Chinese favorites, all done perfectly. The staff is incredible; they remembered us after the first time we went, down to our exact order. And the drinks are great, with 
tiki cocktails that have witty descriptions and cost $7.95. (It might sound like an odd pairing, but it totally works.)”
Chef, The Antler Room

Nicholas Goellner 


Princess Garden


Grand Forks, ND
“On any given Friday night, you’ll often find me at the Grand Forks location of Rhombus Guys. The mini Midwest pizza chain has the best small-town parlor vibe—cozy, rustic, and quirky—and they serve pizzas you can only get away with here, specials like tater tot pizza and wild-rice hotdish pizza. One of my favorite things about Rhombus, however, is that there’s a secret menu option, where you can order any pizza as nachos. My go-to is the Happy Pig nachos, which piles on pulled pork, barbecue sauce, peppers, onions, pineapple, and mozzarella. It helped me get over my initial shock of learning that barbecue sauce pizza is a common thing around here.”
Food blogger and cookbook author, Molly on the Range

Molly Yeh


Rhombus Guys

“This Indianapolis institution is known for its smashed, extra-crispy griddle burgers. Founded in 1918 by Macedonian immigrants to feed nearby railroad workers, it’s still family-owned, extra greasy, and amazing. 
They don’t have a website, but they do have a very entertaining Facebook page.”
Restaurateur, Cafe Patachou

“Pete’s Diner is a greasy spoon, a small, weird diner in the middle of the government buildings. It was never packed, and I could always get a seat. I had a beer budget but Champagne aspirations, so my Sunday ritual was to treat myself to a solo brunch of banana chocolate chip pancakes the size of my face. They were so cheap and filling, which was great since I was post-college and broke as hell! Back during the decidedly non-salad days of my 20s, my favorite food was food that I didn’t have to think about too much. And New York was the perfect place for it—there were at least 15 good restaurants just on the walk from the subway to my apartment, including a couple of primo slice shops that I frequented...let’s flatter myself and say twice a week. Then about three years ago, I moved to Los Angeles where “laid-back” and “chill” might describe the vibes, but the eating is far more complicated. Not only did I have to learn what cavolo nero is (it’s kale; when in doubt, everything here is kale), but more significantly, there was no more absent-mindedly grabbing a slice on the trek home and calling it dinner. Here, I have to actually think about what I want to eat and then drive in a car to go get it. 

That is, until Prime Pizza opened on Fairfax Ave., only a half mile (a.k.a. ten New York City blocks!) from my West Hollywood apartment. Prime serves up downright delightful slices, albeit with a few more veggie options than I remember my Brooklyn shop having (know thy audience). But the best part? I can throw on my headphones and head there on foot, NY-style, which I figure burns off at least a fourth of the pizza calories, L.A.-style.

A few years ago, while I was taking a break from the hustle of New York City, I found myself living in a cabin on a hill in New Hampshire and owning an antique store in town. It was as idyllic as it sounds, except for the fact that it was impossible to find a decent restaurant anywhere nearby. Which is why I often found excuses to drive 45 minutes to Hilltop Café in Wilton, New Hampshire. Situated on the farm that runs one of the oldest CSAs in the country, Hilltop is the best version of a country café—the ingredients come from the farm whenever possible and the food is delicious and reliable.

More importantly, the turkey sandwich is perfect. Its greatness lies in its simplicity: locally made seedy bread with smoked turkey, cheddar, pickled onions, sprouts, and mustard finished on a panini press (never underestimate a panini press). It’s the type of sandwich that reminds you of your childhood lunch but upgraded for adults. And it was always exactly what I wanted.

Ask the average New Yorker or Angeleno what a momo is and they’ll probably come up empty. 
But ask a resident of sleepy Bloomington, Indiana, 
and not only can they identify the comforting 
Tibetan dumpling, they’ll point you toward Anyetsang’s Little Tibet Restaurant. 

The local institution has been serving Himalayan food since 1998, but this cuisine has been a town mainstay for decades. The Dalai Lama’s eldest brother, Tibetan exile Thubten Norbu, was a lauded Indiana University professor and in 1979 founded what is one of America’s only Tibetan cultural centers, right here in Bloomington. Little Tibet’s original owner, Thupten Anyetsang, had said he wanted the place to feel like a humble Tibetan home. It’s hard to miss the quaint Craftsman’s hand-painted blue-and-yellow sign, where a cartoon yak poses in front of snow-capped peaks. The limestone porch is strung with prayer flags and satin tapestries and decorated with framed photos of the Dalai Lama and dusty vases holding fresh-cut flowers. 

Now owned by Anyetsang’s nephew, Pema Wangchen, Little Tibet offers a glimpse into the surprisingly transcultural community surrounding it. Here you’ll find a cross-section of exchange students, born-and-bred Hoosiers, Buddhists, Baptists, and everyone in between, all chatting it up over red lentil soup; hot, buttery Temo buns; and Kham Amdo Thukpa, a spicy meat and vegetable stew with crunchy green onions, daikon, and thick, chewy noodles cut from plump slabs of dumpling dough.
 
About a month into my Ph.D. program in Bloomington, I went on a date at Little Tibet. We bent over a platter of Tsel momos, pillowy purses stuffed with tender cabbage, pan-fried until crisp around the edges, and drenched in hot sauce. The hot crackling dumpling skin gave way to a melt-in-your-mouth mishmash of sticky, toothsome dough and fragrant vegetables. The relationship might have fizzled out, but the restaurant, a few blocks from my apartment at the time and imbued with a welcoming atmosphere you can’t find at the grab-and-go sub shop, stuck.

Photo by Anna Powell Teeter

Writer

Meredith Heil

A Tibetan Oasis with Ties to the Dalai Lama in a Sleepy Indiana Town

“My” Harold’s was No. 62. Harold’s Chicken is one
of Chicago’s most beloved food chains, known for its fried melt-in-your-mouth chicken. And my loyalty was to No. 62, at Wabash and East Harrison, a brief walk from my classes at Columbia College Chicago.
I frequented it so often, my usual (six-piece, all drumettes, extra white bread, sharp and vinegary mild sauce on errythang) would be started a few moments after I walked in. 

In a deeply segregated city, Harold’s brings Chicagoans of all stripes together. They order at bulletproof glass–encased counters and feast in the no-aesthetic aesthetic of white subway tiles punctuated by red paneled walls.

I came to discover everyone had “their” Harold’s:
an ex-partner would eat only at No. 14,  convinced they changed the grease more often thus providing
a superior fry and taste. She refused to eat at No. 62 while we dated, even though it was closer than driving to Hyde Park for the same chicken, prepared the same way, in the same fat.

When summer finally arrived after the brutal Chicago winter, I’d celebrate by taking the bus to 12th Street Beach and nom on a six-piece. Fingers sticky with the fluorescent-red tangy sauce, looking out over Lake Michigan, blissed out. That is, until I hear a “damn girl, you ain’t gonna share?” from one of the nearby security guards, and we both laugh, knowing when she’s off her shift, she’s going straight to Harold’s.

Sevilla has been around for about 80 years, so it’s not my place to draw anyone’s attention to it. But it does happen to be 50 feet from my front door in the West Village, which means I know the facade as well as I know my apartment walls. It’s the kind of restaurant that’s still really into its Zagat review but not the kind of place that’s only into its Zagat review.

It’s open late and, magically, there always seem to be two seats open at the well-stocked bar. The house wine is more than decent, the sangria is great, and the drinks come with homemade potato chips that are 90 percent saltlick. It’s the perfect spot to curl up in a red booth and order clams casino, paella, and garlic soup from the mostly Spanish menu. (If you intend on kissing your dining companion, it’s probably a good idea for you both to order this meal.)

The staff still wears waistcoats, and all of them are the ideal blend of courteous, efficient, and gruff. Who likes a waiter who kisses your ass? This isn’t Los Angeles. The place relies pretty heavily on the sauces, the presentation could stand a bit of updating, and the food is not my favorite in the neighborhood (despite the fact that “queso Manchego” is its own dish—respect), but this is all part of Sevilla’s charm. I’ve never had a bad meal—or a bad night—there.

I’m a sucker for any restaurant shaped like a wedge, its front door narrow and set at the intersection of a few corners, its interior a triangle that grows as you walk in. Top Taste, a Jamaican restaurant in Kingston, New York, sits on Hasbrouck Avenue at the triple intersection of Prince Street, Garden Street, and East O’Reilly Street. The shiniest point of the star, it’s a small building brightly painted in green and yellow, the colors of the Jamaican flag. You can smell the curry chicken before you walk in the door.

I love Top Taste for many reasons. There’s Sammy, who owns the restaurant and runs it with his wife, Malenda. Each time I pick up food from them, I’m reminded of the ripple effect of a friendly conversation and how it can carry you for hours after. The shelves are stocked with Jamaican sauces and spices like Grace Jerk BBQ Sauce and Spur Tree Crushed Red Pepper Sauce; it feels like a perpetually unpacked suitcase stuffed with souvenirs from one Kingston to another. And then there’s the food. The food! Sammy’s jerk chicken is flavor all the way to the bone, the meat so tender that there’s no need for a knife. You would leave a bit lighter on your feet if you skipped a piece of whatever cake Malenda baked that morning, but why pass up something this good? My favorite is her coconut and rum cake, a perfect ratio of sweetness to spicy rum.

Top Taste isn’t the food of my home, but it’s the food that makes me feel at home. It helps me tie my life now, married and living in the Hudson Valley, to my childhood. I was raised in Manhattan by parents who both worked full-time. This meant I was also raised in part by Jennie, my babysitter for a decade who remains one of the most important people in my life. Jennie is from Saint Vincent, a Caribbean island about 1,000 miles east of Jamaica. When I was a kid, Jennie cooked Saint Vincentian food like stewed codfish and pelau regularly, and she loved buying Jamaican food from places like Fisherman’s Cove in Brooklyn. She would share all of this food with me, and, with it, herself. When I zoom out, I realize that so much of our bond was built over Styrofoam boxes of brown stew chicken or curried goat with rice and peas, a few fried plantains tucked alongside. When I go to Top Taste, I’m transported back to my childhood kitchen table—and to Jennie’s too.

The next time Jennie comes to visit me and my wife upstate, I can’t wait to take her to Top Taste. The first time I told her about it, I could hear in her voice how relieved she was to know that, even though I don’t live as close to her as I used to, really good Jamaican food was still in reach.

On my first visit to Vientiane Asian Grocery, a Laotian market tucked inside a south Seattle shopping plaza, I had ambitions of stocking up on pantry items—fish sauce, chiles, pickled green peppercorns. But before I even made it into the aisles, I succumbed to the call of a few tables with orange folding chairs at the front of the store: a modest restaurant made bright by fluorescent lights and colorful flowers hanging from the ceiling. After one taste of the house-made spicy pork sausage bursting with lemongrass, chiles, and cilantro, I knew I’d be coming back. 

Because Vientiane is just a short drive from my house, it’s become my go-to place for lunch with my husband or a close friend who lives nearby. Meals that are meant to be short inevitably turn into leisurely lunches with long, heartening conversations. Over
the years, under the approving gaze of the older women who cook the food, as well as the golden Buddhas behind the cash register where you place your order, I’ve enjoyed flash-fried sticky beef jerky and nam khao—a salad made with wonderfully chewy sour pork skin and crispy rice. I've had steaming bowls of fish khao poon, a noodle soup with a fragrant orange broth that sings of citrus, red curry, lemongrass, and coconut. And after each meal, I find myself heading down the far right aisle to the refrigerator case to grab a ziptop bag of the spicy pork sausage that first hooked me—I always want to take a bit of the warmth and flavor of this place home. I’ve got five bags in my freezer.

An engineering professor from central Pennsylvania, my grandfather had dreams of growing old in a university town by the beach. My grandmother, on the other hand, did not, but when my grandpa bought a small house on a whim in 1990, she reluctantly followed him and lived there until she died in 2009.

The one place where I’ve consistently eaten during all those visits is an unassuming little place called Linda’s Seabreeze Cafe. It’s your standard breakfast-and-lunch-only spot where the egg specials come with a pile of greasy, crispy home fries; every plate is garnished with an orange slice and parsley; and you pray that whoever sat at the table before you didn’t double dip their spoon into the jam jar. There’s often
 a wait (a good sign!), but luckily there’s a coffee pot, mugs, and benches set up outside so those 20 minutes don’t feel too dire. Wall-to-wall carpeting absorbs 
the sounds of the 14 tables filled with locals ordering “the usual” and day-trippers fueling up before a day 
at the beach.

Depending on the time of day, I’ll either get two fried eggs with toast or a tuna salad sandwich. I’m well aware that I can make both of those dishes just as well in my grandpa’s kitchen, but that’s exactly why I love it. It’s familiar food that I can eat in peace—the latter being something that’s hard to come by at my grandpa’s home, which functions as a headquarters of sorts for my mom’s quirky, and some might say dysfunctional, side of the family. My mom and her five younger siblings fight over everything from how clean the cutting board is to who last moved my grandma’s ashes (true story—as of 2014 they were placed in the closet of the guest bedroom). Something is always broken and waiting on my uncle to fix—last time I was there it was the hot water and the dishwasher. When the craziness becomes too much to process, like when my uncle dumped a freestanding spiral staircase from the flea market in the driveway, I and whichever immediate family member happens to be with me need a breath of fresh air. And five minutes away, in the calming wall-to-wall carpeted dining room of Linda’s, with a Diet Coke and a too-large side of potatoes that I will inevitably finish, I know I can always get it.

It is difficult to explain to people who have never been to New Mexico what New Mexican food tastes like. They think they know—they’ve all had enchiladas at least once in their life—but they don’t really know, you can’t really know, because it is close to impossible to get good Hatch chile outside of the state. Hatch chile is our local pepper, which is harvested and roasted over two months in late summer, and during that time, the smell fills the air everywhere you go. The chiles are made into sauces—the fresh (spicier) sauce is green, while the sauce made from dried and pulverized chile is a silky rust red; when you order both on a plate, it is called Christmas. Sure, the sauce can be shipped elsewhere, but it never retains the smoky zip of the just-made version, which is why in order to understand what New Mexican food really tastes like, you simply have to be in New Mexico. There is no way around it. Other local delicacies: sopaipillas (fried pillows of dough that you gnaw the corner off of and then fill with watery honey, preferably from a cheap to-go squirt packet), fideos (like spaghetti but soaked in chile sauce), chiles rellenos (a Hatch chile pepper stuffed with cheese and deep-fried; decadent and exquisite). 

You can find all of these items at Richard’s, an unassuming New Mexican joint that lives inside a strip mall off the freeway, and is one of my favorite restaurants in the whole world. It is often the first place I will go when I get off a plane when visiting home, because there is something about being in Albuquerque that feels incomplete without a giant plate of corn tortillas swimming in a moat of red sauce and melted cheddar and a bird’s nest of shredded iceberg lettuce. Richard’s is only open for breakfast and lunch, which is another thing I love about it. The idea is to eat the biggest, most indulgent meal of the day early on and then give yourself the entire afternoon to recover.

Gentrification doesn’t look the same in rural places as it does in cities, but it is still possible for one way of life to edge out another. In Morgantown, West Virginia, where I grew up, it’s not hipsters who gentrify; it’s developers, with shopping centers and chain restaurants offering mass-produced folksiness or fanciness. This is often called progress. The section of highway that was rerouted in 2011 around Ruby and Ketchy’s—a 60-year-old literal mom-and-pop diner—is also progress. But the highway grazes Ruby and Ketchy’s like a crop duster over a field; it redirects traffic around and above it. 

I worried for a long while that one day I would come home and the little boxy building would be gone, and with it my mother’s memories of taking her father to breakfast after his chemotherapy appointments, my memories of fried chicken dinners after basketball games. But the restaurant was, and is, fine. Sometimes we perceive a threat and only then register how much we value what is threatened. When the highway came, I emotionally doubled down on Ruby and Ketchy’s and everything it represented to me about Appalachian life: the soup beans and cornbread (Thursdays), the cabbage rolls (Fridays), the local advertisements on the place mats, the regulars at the counter. I’m not saying that every place should be Ruby and Ketchy’s, but I’m grateful that Ruby and Ketchy’s is still Ruby and Ketchy’s, and that driverly convenience wasn’t what had been keeping it
in business.
